stem: A 17-year-old male with Sickle Cell Disease (SCD) is admitted for a vaso-occlusive crisis in both legs. Based on the documentation in the Hematology Pain Management & Hydration Log tab, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, the two actions the nurse should take, and the two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: Acute vaso-occlusive crisis.
Background: History of HbSS. Triggered by a recent upper respiratory infection and dehydration.
Assessment: Client reports 10/10 stabbing pain in the long bones of the legs. Capillary refill is 4 seconds.
Recommendation: Stabilization of RBC sickling through 'H.O.P.' protocol.

tabs.title: Pain & Hydration Log
tabs.content:
AssessmentFindingGoal
Pain Score (NRS)10/10 (Crying/Restless)< 3/10
IV Fluid Rate50 mL/hr (D5 1/2 NS)Increase to 200 mL/hr
AnalgesiaMorphine 2mg PRN (Last given 3 hrs ago)Scheduled/PCA
Specific Gravity1.035 (High)< 1.015

actionOptions.text: Increase the IV fluid rate to 200 mL/hr (Resuscitation)
Administer IV Morphine on a scheduled or PCA basis
Apply cold packs to the legs to reduce inflammation
Withhold analgesics until the client's pain score is below 5/10

parameterOptions.text: Urine output and specific gravity (Hydration status)

rationale.correct: Vaso-occlusive Crisis (c1) requires immediate intervention to 'un-stick' the RBCs. The priority is 'H.O.P': Hydration, Oxygenation, and Pain relief. The nurse should increase fluids (a1) to dilute the sickled cells and provide scheduled/consistent analgesia (a2) because PRN dosing is often inadequate for severe crisis. Monitoring pain scores (p1) and markers of hydration like specific gravity (p2) is essential to track recovery.
clinicalPearls: Dehydration leads to high blood viscosity, which promotes sickling.
Demerol (Meperidine) is CONTRAINDICATED in SCD patients due to the risk of seizures from normeperidine metabolite accumulation.
Always prioritize IV fluids and pain management.

questionTrap.trap: Setting up a PRN morphine schedule for a sickle cell crisis.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: PRN is for sporadic pain. Sickle cell pain is continuous and severe. Use a PCA pump or 'around-the-clock' (ATC) scheduling.
